definition: variant of 押韻|押韵[ya1 yun4]
see 壓根兒|压根儿[ya4 gen1 r5]
to press/to push down/to keep under (control)/pressure
the final (of a syllable) (Chinese phonology)/rhyme/appeal/charm/(literary) pleasant sound

sentences.english: On rhyme, the two languages find their different ways in making musical effects.
sentences.chinese: 从音韵上讲，汉诗和英诗压韵的方法有很大区别。

sentences.english: The last two lines of this poem don't rhyme properly.
sentences.chinese: 这首诗后两句不怎么压韵。

definition: to rhyme/sometimes written 壓韻|压韵
antithesis (two lines of poetry matching in sense and sound)/to fight/to wage war
rhyming word ending a line of verse/rhyme
level and oblique tones (technical term for Classical Chinese rhythmic poetry)
regular verse/strict poetic form with eight lines of 5, 6 or 7 syllables and even lines rhyming
number of sentences/number of lines (in verse etc)
poetic form consisting of four lines of five syllables, with rhymes on first, second and fourth line
a pre-Tang Dynasty genre of poetry, relatively free in form, usually having four, five, six or seven characters per line
forms of versification/conventions regarding set number of words and lines, choice of tonal patterns and rhyme schemes for various types of Classical Chinese poetic composition/metrical verse
a genre of poetry, developed in the Tang Dynasty, characterized by its strict form
dual/duality/antithesis/coupled phrases (as rhetorical device)/spouse
to flow right off the tongue (of lyrics or poetry)/to recite with ease/catchy (of a song)
to pause at appropriate points in reading aloud unpunctuated writing/to punctuate
names of the tunes to which 詞|词[ci2] poems are composed
clause
foot (syllabic unit in verse)/meter/scansion
